title: If a small black hole (say 10 solar masses) passes near a much larger black hole, is it possible that the counteracting gravity could allow light to escape the event horizon in the direction of the larger black hole? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. Paradoxically (or maybe not) the gravitational gradient is MUCH lower in a big bh. In a stellar bh you would be ripped apart by tidal forces 1000 km before you hit the event horizon, whereas in a SMBH you won’t even notice when you pass the event horizon. This means that a small bh close to a big bh will be largely unaffected (of course they will orbit each other and give off gravitational waves/energy and soon merge)
